newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - UK retail sales to bounce back in August.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - UK retail sales to bounce back in August.

text.p: British retail sales will have bounced back strongly in August, after a surprise drop in July, unless a wealth of anecdotal evidence is completely wide of the mark, analysts said on Monday.

A Reuter poll of economists forecast a 0.5 percent jump in retail sales volumes in August, taking year-on-year growth up to 3.5 percent. In July, a shock 0.6 percent fall took the annual rate down to 2.2 percent.
Marian Bell, economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said July's figures flew in the face of a variety of survey findings.
"Retail sales growth fell back in July. This seemed to contradict survey evidence that retail sales growth remained strong," she said.
On Wednesday, when the August figures are released, that circle should be squared she said, forecasting a 0.7 percent monthly rise in sales.

Bell noted the British Retail Consortium's August sales monitor showed retail sales rose 6.9 percent year-on-year on a value basis. Moreover, the Confederation of British Industry's August distributive trades survey showed the largest balance of firms reporting an increase in sales since 1988.
And weekly department store sales data from the John Lewis Partnership showed August sales up 18.5 percent on average from a year ago.

Ciaran Barr, UK economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said July's sales could have dropped for any number of reasons -- the ending of Euro 96, the European football championships held in England, a spell of mild weather, or a reaction to the 1.4 percent leap in June's sales.
"Whatever the cause, both the BRC and CBI surveys indicate that retail sales growth picked up again in August," he said. "The buoyancy of recent notes in circulation data support this."

David Philpotts, UK economist at Schroders, said the CBI survey indicated a particularly strong performance from furniture and carpet sales in August. "But a relatively broad-based expansion in expenditure is likely."
He said the headline figure for July was disappointing but noted that even that month showed a firm underlying trend.
"On a three-month-on-three-month basis, all sectors aside from food and non-store sales still reported an annualised increase in excess of five percent."

Analysts at HSBC James Capel agreed. "Given strength of sales in June, it is hardly surprising that volumes fell somewhat in July," they said. "Retail sales, like most other economic series, do not go up in straight lines."

Their forecast matched the consensus for year-on-year sales growth of 3.5 percent in August. "There is little doubt that the trend in retail sales volumes remains very firmly upwards," they said in a client note.
